full_threads.body:
Weekly news, tips & laughs :) -

June 14, 2022

The monday.com weekly

monday's take on the latest work trends - sent on Tuesdays

Inside this issue

  • Workplace trends

  • Our new LinkedIn community
  • Helping your team members maximize productivity
  • Quotable news
  • Question of the week
  • Just for laughs

Workplace trends

Burnout

Human resource workers are beyond burned out

Since the start of the pandemic, human resource professionals have been forced to take on more than ever before. Employees are quitting their jobs at record levels - often publicly via social media, - companies are struggling to offer high enough salaries and good enough benefits to retain talent, mental health issues have come to the forefront, workers are feeling the strain of blurred work-life boundaries, and employers are stuck in an endless puzzle of return-to-office plans. And through it all, HR teams have never been more vital - or drained. Roughly 98% of them are completely burned out, according to a recent study by Workvivo. Companies must now grapple with how to ensure their HR teams maintain their own work-life balance as they continue to build a better workplace environment for their employees.

Economy

You're not imagining it - products are shrinking

In the face of rising inflation, companies around the world have started to shrink the size of their products without lowering prices.

  • The amount of tissues in a small Kleenex box shrunk from 65 to 60.
  • Gatorade replaced 32-ounce bottles with a 28-ounce version.
  • The $7.99 chicken wings at Domino's Pizza went from 10-pieces to eight.

The concept behind this practice? Consumers will prefer a slightly shrunken product over a slightly larger price tag - or they won't notice the size change whatsoever. While shrinkflation is a time-tested method of dealing with wholesale price shifts, the surge in the cost of raw goods, transportation, and food has caused this trend to spike, affecting grocery shelves and restaurants en masse. Some experts worry that businesses are taking advantage of these supply constraints for profiteering.

Consumption

Retailers are way overstocked

Target, Gap, Walmart, and other major US retailers that had rushed to stock their shelves early in the pandemic are now sitting on $45 billion in inventory - an increase of 26% from the same period last year. How did this happen? In trying to solve Covid-related shortages, retailers stocked up on goods consumers don't want to buy anymore, like casual clothes, exercise equipment, and home goods. These days, as travel returns and many are back in the office, buyer preferences have shifted toward experience-goods like luggage and cosmetics. In this inflationary environment, the one piece of good news for consumers is that this excess supply will likely lead many retailers to discount items that have not been moving off the shelves.

We launched a monday insights LinkedIn community as a space to discuss relevant news updates, share work insights, and connect to one another. Join the community.

Helping your team members maximize productivity

by monday.com
 

We all have too much to do and not enough hours in the day to do it. As a manager, there's a good chance you've figured out how to plan and prioritize your work. But what about your team members? How can you help them stay productive and best manage their time?

As a boss in today's complex, often hybrid workplace, the real challenge is managing your team's collective workload, according to an article in the Harvard Business Review. And to be clear, managing that workload doesn't mean micromanaging - it means setting an example, understanding the challenges individuals are facing, and helping them effectively organize their time.

How to produce a productive team:

Set an example

When you can model what good time management practices look like, your team has something to reference as they build out their own workflows. Be strategic about the meetings you attend, the emails you engage with, and the projects you take on, so your team can follow your lead. Also, if you're overloaded, you likely won't have the bandwidth to help your team members maximize their own time.

Align expectations

Make sure you have regular one-on-ones with all your team members that are dedicated to setting goals and expectations, prioritizing work, and defining next steps. Get aligned on the outcomes you are trying to achieve and then give them the reins to decide on their own how to get there. Remember, your approach may not work the best for them, so avoid micromanaging - simply give them the information they need and then allow them to take the lead.

Additionally, whenever possible, be explicit about how much energy you think should be invested into each project. For example, to prepare for an upcoming brainstorming session, should they spend a couple minutes jotting down some ideas or invest a few hours into building out a presentation?

Encourage honesty

Check in on your team members. Create a dynamic in which they can feel comfortable sharing the challenges they are facing so that you can better understand how to support them. Let your team members know that if they are feeling stretched thin, you'll be there to take some of the load off and, when possible, try to reallocate certain projects. This can make a huge impact on their experience and ensure you're properly balancing the collective workload among members of your team.

Provide thoughtful feedback

Staying transparent also means giving your team members feedback as often as possible and ensuring that nothing comes as a shock later on. Don't wait for a formal evaluation to give employees guidance and critiques. And, when something isn't hitting the mark, be sure to explain why so that they have clarity on what's needed going forward.

Be strategic with everyone's time

While certain meetings are crucial to sharing information, brainstorming strategies, and making effective decisions, let's be honest - not all meetings are necessary. And not all your team members need to attend each and every one. So, think through who actually needs to join, make sure every meeting has an agenda, and share relevant material beforehand to maximize time together. This way, meetings won't be too time-consuming and they will actually produce the intended results.

Take breaks

As a manager, it's your responsibility to set boundaries, encourage your team members to take breathers throughout the day, and sign off at a reasonable hour. You set the tone for your team, so be intentional about what expectations you're setting. Research shows that taking time to disconnect and recharge can have powerful effects on productivity, stress, and morale. So, demonstrate what it means to prioritize a work-life balance and support your employees in doing the same!

Quotable News

Bees are now legally considered fish in California under the state's endangered species law, as of last week's court ruling.

"This decision essentially allows the state of California to protect bumblebees and other imperiled species of insects"

Sarina Jepsen, Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation Spokesperson

The US lifted its Covid test requirement for international travel. The health agency reported that it will continue to monitor the state of the pandemic and will reassess the need for a testing requirement if circumstances change.

"This step is possible because of the progress we've made in our fight against COVID-19"

Xavier Becerra, U.S. Health Secretary
